content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Trinity College</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/194746" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>Trinity College</subtitle> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/194746</id> <updated>2015-03-12T02:54:51Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-12T02:54:51Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Francis Bacon and the 'Interpretation of Nature' in the Late Renaissance</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246267" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Serjeantson, Richard</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246267</id> <updated>2014-11-04T22:25:39Z</updated> <published>2014-10-27T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Francis Bacon and the 'Interpretation of Nature' in the Late Renaissance Serjeantson, Richard The \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinterpretation of nature\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (interpretatio naturae) is the leading idea in Francis Bacon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds (1561\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd1626) natural philosophy. But by contrast with his ideas about method, induction, or experiment, the significance of the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinterpretation of nature\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd has received very little scholarly attention. This paper tests the originality of Bacon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds idea by means of a focused survey of existing forms of renaissance natural knowledge\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAristotelian and anti-Aristotelian natural philosophy, Galenic and Paracelsian medicine, natural magic, physiognomy, natural history\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbefore turning to consider the much more prominent place of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinterpretation\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in the fields of renaissance logic, revealed and natural theology, and law. It finds that Bacon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds application of the idea of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinterpretation\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to nature was highly original, but also that certain important aspects of his conception have analogies in renaissance civil law. The article concludes by exploring the implications of these findings for a recent body of scholarship in the history of the sciences that invokes the notion of the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinterpretation of nature\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to characterize pre-Baconian natural philosophy more generally. </summary> <dc:date>2014-10-27T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Consciousness and the Physical World</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/245189" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Josephson, Brian D</name> </author> <author> <name>Ramachandran, Vilayanur S</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/245189</id> <updated>2015-01-28T12:03:26Z</updated> <published>1978-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Consciousness and the Physical World Josephson, Brian D; Ramachandran, Vilayanur S Edited proceedings of an interdisciplinary symposium on consciousness held at the University of Cambridge in January 1978, including a foreword by Freeman J. Dyson. Chapter authors: G. Vesey, R.L. Gregory, H.C. Longuet-Higgins, N.K. Humphrey, H.B. Barlow, D.M. MacKay, B.D. Josephson,  M. Roth, V.S. Ramachandran, S. Padfield, and (editorial summary only) E. Noakes. The main file in this deposition is a pdf file containing the scanned pages of the Proceedings. Additional files OCR.txt and OCR.pdf (the latter having the same pagination as the book) are included to simplify search, etc.  Because of their automated creation using software, the accuracy of the OCR files cannot be guaranteed, though some checking has been carried out.  In the scanned version, entering 'go to page n' in a pdf reader will access the pair of pages 2n and 2n+1.  Alternatively, go to the contents pages (accessible via 'go to page', entering 'contents' at the prompt) for the numbers to use with 'go to' for specific chapters.  \ufffd\ufffd By arrangement with the publishers, the editors (Brian D Josephson and Vilayanur S Ramachandran) are the present copyright holders. They grant permission for the use of the material in this book in accord with the terms of the CC licence below. </summary> <dc:date>1978-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
